Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Building Tech Talent and Connecting Student Pipelines to Entrepreneurial Ecosystems at Historically Black Colleges and Universities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This 2-year planning grant enables the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities, United Negro College Fund, and Thurgood Marshall College Fund to develop a national Historically Black Colleges and Universities focused effort to broaden participation in computer and information science. This project develops a framework for achieving the following key objectives: 1) Increase the number and yield of bachelor's degrees Historically Black Colleges and Universities award in computer and information science and related fields, 2) Increase the readiness of Historically Black Colleges and Universities' science, technology, engineering and math graduates for tech workforce and tech job creation, 3) Increase the number of African American computer and information science doctoral students at all U.S. doctoral programs from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (undergrad degree), and 4) Increase the institutional capacity - including research and development - of Historically Black Colleges and Universities to achieve the above stated goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the exception of a few (Cheyney University founded in 1837, Lincoln University in 1853, and Wilberforce University in 1856), most HBCUs were founded after the Civil War and at a time when American society was transitioning from the first to the second Industrial Revolution — a period marked by the rise of electricity as source of energy, traffic controls, and the expansion and modernization of transportation including the transcontinental railroads. It was also the period during which many of America’s greatest research intensive higher education institutions were founded — including the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (1861), Carnegie Mellon University (1900), Georgia Institute of Technology (1885), and Rockefeller University (1901). Yet HBCUs and the aforementioned majority-white institutions were neither founded with the same mission nor expectations for intellectual contributions to the American academic scientific and engineering enterprise. Essentially, HBCUs were founded to solve a societal problem — how do you move formerly enslaved Africans in America toward self-sufficiency?

 

Between 2009 and 2019, Morehouse School of Medicine was granted 63 patents.  Howard University is next with 53 patents granted. Howard also made news headlines a few years ago for its groundbreaking partnership with Google, which established a campus at the company’s headquarters for HBCU computer science students to study and learn in Silicon Valley. There are also many HBCUs that lack the resources or research activity to support a tech transfer office. However, all HBCUs have the asset of talented students and faculty, who with the right support can expand the innovation footprint of even the least resourced colleges.

 

There’s no question that HBCUs have not had the funding, research capacity, and existing corporate relationships to fully take advantage of new opportunities in technology transfer and commercialization. Howard University (HU) ranked 203rd out of all universities (more than 1,000 institutions) in research and development expenditures (R&D) in 2017 with expenditures of nearly $46 million. This figure made them the highest ranked HBCU. In total, 17 HBCUs including HBCU medical schools occupied spots in the ranking from 203rd to 305th and with total R&D expenditures of $390 million. If these 17 HBCU institutions were one university, they still would only rank 61st nationally in R&D expenditures. Even combined, these HBCUs would still trail the top 15 universities that spent close to $1 billion or more in R&D.

For the past two years, with planning grant support from the National Science Foundation, the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU) worked with colleagues from the United Negro College Fund (UNCF) and other HBCU intermediaries to convene a diverse group of stakeholders focusing on this task. The group included science, technology, engineering, math and computer science (STEM-CS) faculty and higher education leaders from HBCUs and majority institutions, tech-industry engineers and hiring managers, and representatives from non-profit organizations whose programs impact the African American STEM-CS pipeline, philanthropy, tech-accelerators, and investors. The following are recommendations for a strategy to build a framework for realizing the potential of HBCUs in innovation, commercialization, and entrepreneurship.

  1. Sharing Knowledge - HBCUs greatest asset is each other. Participants all agreed on the exponential value of coming together and learning from one another. 
    1. To facilitate this shared learning across the sector, APLU, UNCF, and the 1890 Foundation have launched efforts to create an HBCU-wide resource center for sharing best practices and innovative approaches to tech entrepreneurship.
  2. Sharing Resources - Maximizing the HBCU community’s assets requires sharing resources, i.e., funding, research expertise, intellectual property, as well as staff, faculty, and students.
    1. Establishing an HBCU-wide hub that would have knowledge of all the research and sponsored programs on HBCU campuses nation-wide and therefore be able to aggregate assets to take advantage of opportunities such as federal grants or philanthropic gifts.
  3. Creating a Culture of Innovation, Research, and Entrepreneurship:
  •  
    • Innovative Leadership - HBCU leaders could benefit from the technology start-up approach.
      •  
    •  Innovative Faculty -HBCUs can create consortia to share existing faculty across campuses to reduce teaching loads and provide faculty with more time for research.
    •  Innovative Students - students should be trained not just to work at leading tech companies, but to start ones of their own.
    • Innovative Structures - HBCUs must dismantle current structures that maintain siloes. A robust ecosystem serves the entire campus as well as the broader community and therefore requires connection and collaboration across traditional lines of division.
